ratings.comment: Exams are tough but are curved a lot. I probably goy about a 65% in this class but it ended up being an A!

Kiselev is insanely smart and would really fit better in an upper level math course. He is helpful and provides examples. You will need to put in a decent amount of work outside of class. Exam averages are very low but curved fairly. He is a great guy and really cares about the subject. He has a really cute accent too

I really liked Professor Kiselev. A lot of people say he tests on proofs but he really only put a couple on the final exam. Plus, he tells you exactly which ones he is going to pick from. I managed an A without too much work. Prior calc experience is EXTREMELY helpful.

I've always been really good at math but I found him to be a really difficult professor. His exams are so hard and the averages were usually around 50%. He goes really fast in lecture and jumps right into the hardest problems in the book for homework. I ended up spending the majority of my time on this class. Definitely go to your TA's office hours

Great guy! He understands and teaches the material well and I understand the course very very well! But here's the downside. His exams are very very very difficult. He will test on every single thing. If you do not understand one little thing you are screwed. He teaches it as a very high level math class and expects you to preform to that standard.

His exams are very difficult for a calc 1 class. He would be much better teaching a higher level class because he expects you know every single rule and how to not get lost in very very complex derivatives and anti derivatives. It's so complex it doesn't show your actual understanding of the equations

Alex Kiselev is by far the best professor I have taken at UW-Madison so far. Although his tests are quite challenging and the curve is difficult, the class is very interesting. He keeps the class up-beat with his sense of humor. Also, he is the most knowledgeable professor in his area of teaching that I have seen at my time at UW-Madison.

A very friendly, funny guy with a sense of humor and a slight Russian accent.  Teaches in a very theoretical manner, focuses heavily on proofs and definitions.  Lectures at a fast pace and plows through 6-10 chalkboards per class.  Although he gives lots of examples they don't always apply, and his exams are super difficult. UW textbook is useless

I am pretty on the fence about this guy. He's nice and genuinely tries to be helpful, but I thought his teaching methods were very vague and confusing. I had an incredibly great calc teacher in high school, which is probably the only reason I passed his class. My TA was bad too so that didn't help. His exams are much, much harder than homework.

Prof Kiselev made calculus relatively painless. Although a lot of lecture time was spent on proofs he does a good job allowing time for question and gives plenty of examples. However the text book which accompanies this class is produced by the university and is filled with errors in the text as well as the solutions.
Good teacher, focuses a lot rigorously solving problems and proofs. My advice, memorize the proofs worth at least 20 points of every exam! Pretty basic calc otherwise.

Okay professor. When I went to his office hours, he just ran through the problems in a very theoretical way, which was not helpful. I got a bad grade on one exam and it screwed me over for the course. Be prepared to do a lot of reading on your own. He crammed a ton of info in the last 2 weeks because he ran out of time. Overall, not bad, not great.

Pretty good teacher; really nice and does a good job making sure everyone understands.  I definitely advise memorizing the formal definitions and proofs of everything, because he loves to put those on the tests.  The tests were hard and there was always one impossible extra credit question at the end.
Well-written notes and great teaching. I promise you won't sleep in his class.

Amazing professor.  He presents tons of proofs and always makes sure that everyone understands every step.  He moves very quickly through material so you need to pay attention in class.  The textbook, Real Analysis by Frank Morgan, is short and really clear.  Take Kiselev's class if you get the chance!

great professor. accent was not difficult to understand. made jokes frequently to lighten the mood of a complicated day in lecture. explained things very well and was helpful after lecture and during office hours.

He does have an accent, but he is still easy to understand. His practice exams are pretty representative of his upcoming exams. Just watch out for that one tricky question that might psychologically damage you for 5 minutes. He loves proofs though, so be sure to have them memorized word for word.

Take this guy if you want to be a math major/engineer. You will do proofs and you will need to memorize them WORD FOR WORD to pass. Proofs were ~40% of every test. Let me repeat: YOU NEED TO MEMORIZE THE PROOFS TO PASS.

Kiselev was a good professor and always provided help when needed. His requiring of you to memorize proofs sucked. Also his tests are tricky. They may be five questions but they have about five parts. His curve is always extremely generous. Make sure you get a good TA. GET JAMES as your TA if you can.

Pretty nice guy. At the start of class he solves a few tricky homework problems and makes sure the class understands them. Exams aren't bad if you go to the review sessions and are curved fairly. This guy loves math and also has a sense of humor.

I really enjoyed Professor Kiselev's class. If you put in the work and attend lecture, then it isn't that hard of a class. Having a good TA also helps a lot; I was fortunate to have one. He teaches the class well and gets the large class involved. You can tell he loves what he is doing. I recommend him.

Kiselev was a pretty good teacher...A little russian accent, but understandable...He likes proofs, but lectures aren't that bad because he is a pretty funny guy. Tests are quite fair, b/c he gives a practice test very similar to the real tests

Loved loved loved kiselev! you can tell he is very intelligent and is funny during class. Gives very fair exams as well as practice exams and lists of definitions and proofs that may be on the test. If you use your TA and study the practice test you have a good chance of getting a good grade in the class!
Good teacher.  Very proof heavy, but really knows his stuff.  Gives fair tests, will posts review sheets and practice exams online.  Says some really funny things sometimes too.

I actually enjoyed having kiselev as my teacher. If you go to lectures and study proofs and definitions you will have no problem getting a good grade in his class. tests are super fair and if you study (which i regret not doing) you will def. get an A. previous calc experience did help a lot, but discussions help too if you havent taken calc before
I like him.

Kiselev relies heavily on proofs and definitions. Prepare to spend much of your studying time on memorizing word for word definitions.  Tests are only about 5 questions long, but theyre worth a lot. USE YOUR TA if you want a good grade.  He does have a great sense of humor though :)

Professor Kiselev is easily my favorite professor this semester. He is funny, his tests aren't super challenging (I took calc in h.s. though; if you go over his review information you will do fine, even if you've missed class. He is a kind and understanding man and I highly recommend him over any other calc prof!
I feel he taught the subject very well. He does rely on a lot of proofs, but he will also do examples of problems if asked. Kind and willing to help.
He has a good sense of humor and clearly loves his job.

For someone who did not take a calc class in high school, this is a very difficult course no matter who is teaching it.  Kiselev is especially hard to follow because he teaches as though his students already know the material.  My advice is to go to other discussion sections until you find a TA  you can understand and switch into his/her class.

He ia a very likable professor, but not the greatest teacher.  Sometimes did not adequately prepare us for the exams and there were questions that were completely foreign material.  Grades homework and tests hard, and is not very organized.  Better than most Math professors though.  If you take him be prepared to work hard and on your own.

Very funny guy.  He is a very good prof even though the material is tough.  Tests are fair, and he even puts theorems and definitions that are simple memorization.  If you do the homework and attend class, you'll do fine.
Amazing professor and really interesting lectures.  His exams are ridiculously hard and very theory based, expect to memorize lots of proofs
I love this man. His exams are seriously difficult and very theory based, but you just can't hate the guy. He's  funny and has an accent and basically he made me love math. And I hate math.

Excellent lecturer, and somewhat humorous.  Makes class much more interesting than it can be with other Professors.  His exams typically are hard and knowing the material presented in class well does not necessarily mean you'll do well on the exam.
No Comments

A very knowledgable and enthusiastic professor. He does a good job of explaining concepts and theory. Passing his exams requires a bit of strategy -- you need to be very familiar with the underlying principles and proofs. He doesn't assign too much homework, so it's important to take your time on it.

Hilarous professor who gives out extra credit towards homework grade if you correct him on dumb mistakes he may make while doing examples.  If you take notes on the proofs, you just have to memorize them for the test.  He gives a practice midterm exam and proofs/rules you may need to state for the test and he basically tells you whats on the test.A

Very entertaining in class. Definetly the best professor I've heard of for math. He has funny little jokes all the time. The math is hard, but its prob just because Calc 221 is hard. He's very fair. He gives practice midterms for each test and a list of the proofs and def's that you need to know for each test. You also get to drop one of 3 midterms

Compared to other math prof's, prof kiselev is great! he's a pretty funny guy sometimes and his explanations are always clear. If he senses that the lecture hall doesnt get it, he goes back to explain everything. Definitely a good professor to get. TAKE KISELEV INSTEAD OF RAM IF U WANT TO HAVE A LIFE!!!
Crazy proofs

He's a really smart guy, definetly knows what he's talking about...but he is hard to understand. His specialty is in analyzing equations and such, so proofs really fascinate him and you see that in his class. Difficult to understand sometimes, not because of his accent, but just by the way he says things, in mathematical terms.

Great guy, may have been a communist but who hasn't.  This guy is incredibly smart and can teach but sometimes he gets carried away with crazy, outlandish proofs which hopefully are harmless and not on the test.  Very reasonable in his homework assignment but i have  good TA
